The rise of remote work is leading to a shift in demand for commercial real estate in major cities worldwide. As more companies adopt remote work policies, they are requiring less physical office space. This has led to a decrease in demand for commercial office space in cities. Additionally, with fewer people commuting to work, there is less demand for retail and hospitality space. 

As a result, landlords and property owners in major cities are facing downward pressure on rental prices, declining occupancy rates, and vacancy rates. This has been seen in cities like New York and San Francisco, which historically had high occupancy and rental rates for commercial office space. Landlords are now offering rent concessions and other incentives to attract tenants to lease spaces.

However, the rise of remote work is also leading to new opportunities for commercial real estate markets. With the increased demand for flexible and collaborative workspaces, there is a growing demand for co-working spaces, which offer short-term leases and shared amenities. Additionally, some companies are looking to lease smaller satellite offices in suburban areas to provide employees with easier access to work while avoiding the high costs of city centers.

Overall, the rise of remote work is causing disruptions in the commercial real estate markets in major cities worldwide, but it is also creating new opportunities for landlords and property owners who are willing to adapt to changing market conditions.
